philosophy: Components are the vocabulary of interaction

button.description: Primary interactive element for user actions. Buttons communicate clear, actionable choices that drive results.
button.usage: Use buttons for primary actions, form submissions, CTAs. Limit to 1-2 buttons per section to maintain hierarchy.

variants.name: Primary
variants.purpose: Main actions that drive business results

specs.note: Visible focus indicator for keyboard navigation

accessibility: Color contrast: 4.5:1 minimum for all states (WCAG AA)
aria-disabled='true' for disabled state (maintain in tab order)
Never rely on color alone - use text/icons for meaning

dos_donts.do: Use primary buttons for main conversion actions

dos_donts.rationale: Clear, results-focused language matches brand voice

dos_donts.do: Limit to 1 primary button per section
dos_donts.rationale: Prevents decision paralysis, focuses user intent
Easier touch target, better mobile UX

dos_donts.dont: Use all caps for button text
dos_donts.rationale: Reduces readability, feels aggressive (not friendly brand voice)

dos_donts.dont: Use more than 2 CTA buttons on a page
dos_donts.rationale: Golden amber should be reserved for highest-value actions
Users need to understand why action is unavailable

input.description: Text input fields for collecting user data. Designed for clarity and ease of completion.
input.usage: Use for single-line text entry: names, emails, phone numbers, search queries.

error_message.display: Show immediately on blur if invalid

accessibility: Always pair input with <label> using for/id attributes
Use aria-describedby for helper text and errors
Use autocomplete attributes for better UX and accessibility
Minimum 16px font size to prevent zoom on iOS
Error messages must be programmatically associated
Color contrast: 4.5:1 for all text (WCAG AA)

dos_donts.do: Use clear, specific labels (not placeholders alone)
dos_donts.rationale: Labels remain visible when typing - better usability

dos_donts.do: Show validation on blur, not while typing
dos_donts.rationale: Reduces cognitive load, feels less aggressive

dos_donts.do: Provide specific error messages with solutions

dos_donts.dont: Use placeholder as the only label
dos_donts.rationale: Disappears on focus, bad for accessibility and memory

dos_donts.dont: Validate while user is still typing
Use red for anything except errors
Make inputs shorter than 40 characters wide
dos_donts.rationale: Users can't review what they typed - causes errors

textarea.description: Multi-line text input for longer content like messages, descriptions, feedback.
textarea.usage: Use when user needs to enter 2+ sentences. Avoid for single-line data.
accessibility: aria-describedby for character count and helper text
Allow vertical resize only (prevent layout breaks)
Auto-grow option: expand as user types (max-height: 400px)

dos_donts.do: Show character count for limited fields
Set appropriate min-height based on expected content

dos_donts.rationale: Users can adjust to their comfort level
Regular input field is more appropriate

select.description: Dropdown menu for selecting one option from a list of choices.
select.usage: Use for 5-15 options. For <5 options use radio buttons, for >15 use autocomplete.
accessibility: Use semantic <select> or ARIA-compliant custom select
Type-ahead search (type 'A' jumps to first 'A' option)
Minimum option height: 40px for touch targets

dos_donts.do: Sort options logically (alphabetical or by frequency)

dos_donts.rationale: Makes selection explicit, prevents accidental submission
Radio buttons show all options at once - better UX
Users may not notice, causes form errors

checkbox.description: Toggle control for binary choices or multiple selections from a list.
checkbox.usage: Use for opt-ins, multi-select lists, or enabling/disabling features.

states.name: Indeterminate
states.use_case: Parent checkbox when some children selected

accessibility: Space key to toggle checkbox when focused

dos_donts.do: Use positive language (Receive updates, not Don't send updates)

dos_donts.rationale: Toggle switch is clearer for state changes

radio.description: Mutually exclusive selection from a group of options. Only one can be selected at a time.
radio.usage: Use for 2-5 mutually exclusive choices. For more options, use select dropdown.
accessibility: Use semantic <input type='radio'> with same name attribute
Only one radio in group can be selected
Arrow keys navigate between radios in group
One radio should be selected by default or none

dos_donts.do: Pre-select the most common or recommended option
dos_donts.rationale: Reduces decision time, shows best practice
Vertical = faster to scan and compare
Single checkbox or toggle is clearer

dos_donts.dont: Allow deselection of all radios after selection

toggle.description: On/off switch for binary state changes. Visually communicates immediate state.
toggle.usage: Use for settings, feature toggles, preferences that take effect immediately.
accessibility: aria-label or associated label via for/id
Visual state must be clear without color alone

dos_donts.do: Provide clear labels for both states
Use success color (accent) for on state

dos_donts.rationale: Toast or status message confirms action

dos_donts.dont: Use for actions that require confirmation
Use if change takes time to process
dos_donts.rationale: Loading state isn't clear in toggle

card.description: Container for grouping related content and actions. Foundation of content organization.
card.usage: Use for blog posts, products, features, team members, case studies.
accessibility: Use semantic HTML: <article> for content, <div> for UI cards
Interactive cards: tabindex='0' + keyboard enter/space handlers
Don't nest interactive elements (buttons inside clickable card)

dos_donts.do: Use consistent card heights in grid layouts
Limit actions to 1-2 buttons per card
Use aspect ratio containers for images
Make entire card clickable for single-action cards

dos_donts.dont: Make entire card clickable if it has multiple actions
dos_donts.rationale: Confusing interaction - where does click go?
Creates visual confusion and hierarchy issues

dos_donts.dont: Use more than 2 box-shadow levels on page
dos_donts.rationale: Too much depth flattens the hierarchy
Line length becomes difficult to read

badge.description: Small label for status, categories, counts, or quick visual classification.
badge.usage: Use for statuses, tags, counts, new features, notifications.
accessibility: Use semantic meaning: <span> for static, <button> for interactive
Don't rely on color alone - use text/icons
For status badges, include aria-live='polite' if they update

dos_donts.rationale: Long text defeats purpose of quick scanning
Use helper text or tooltips instead

dos_donts.dont: Use more than 3 badge colors per page

alert.description: Prominent messages for important information, success confirmations, warnings, or errors.
alert.usage: Use for system messages, validation feedback, important announcements.
accessibility: Focus close button when alert appears (if dismissible)

dos_donts.rationale: Users scan alerts quickly - be direct

dos_donts.do: Include specific actions or next steps
dos_donts.rationale: Example: 'Email enviado. Verifique sua caixa de entrada.'
Reduces clutter, confirms action without lingering

dos_donts.do: Keep errors visible until user dismisses
dos_donts.rationale: User may need to reference while fixing

dos_donts.dont: Stack more than 3 alerts at once
Use technical jargon in error messages
dos_donts.rationale: Brand voice: friendly and accessible, not technical

modal.description: Overlay dialog that focuses user attention on a specific task or decision.
modal.usage: Use for confirmations, forms, detailed views. Should be purposeful and concise.

variants.name: Content
variants.footer: optional (Close button in header may suffice)

variants.name: Full-screen Mobile
variants.purpose: Better mobile UX for complex modals

accessibility: Use role='dialog' or role='alertdialog' for urgent modals
Focus first interactive element on open
Clicking overlay closes modal (optional based on context)
Return focus to trigger element on close
Prevent body scroll when modal is open

dos_donts.do: Use for focused tasks that require completion
dos_donts.rationale: Modals interrupt flow - make it worthwhile

dos_donts.do: Provide clear way to close (X button + ESC + overlay click)
Limit to 1 modal at a time

dos_donts.rationale: Overuse creates frustration - consider inline alternatives
Feels aggressive, blocks content, hurts SEO

dos_donts.dont: Disable overlay click-to-close without good reason

dos_donts.rationale: Modals should be dismissible, not essential

link.description: Text-based navigation element. Foundation of web navigation and content relationships.
link.usage: Use for navigation, inline text links, and external resources.
accessibility: Use semantic <a> element with href attribute
Link text must be descriptive (not 'click here')
External links: include aria-label or visible indicator
Skip links for keyboard navigation to main content

dos_donts.rationale: WCAG requirement - don't rely on color alone
Users should know they're leaving the site
Easier to scan and tap on mobile
Not descriptive for screen readers or scanning

dos_donts.dont: Open external links in same tab without warning

dos_donts.rationale: Hard to distinguish link from regular text
Use buttons instead - links are for navigation

navigation.description: Primary site navigation for moving between major sections and pages.
navigation.usage: Use for main menu, mobile menu, footer navigation.

states.name: Scrolled
states.note: Add shadow when user scrolls down

accessibility: Focus visible on all interactive elements
Skip to main content link (visually hidden, focus visible)
Keyboard navigation: Tab, Enter, Arrow keys

dos_donts.rationale: Frustrating pattern - navigation should be accessible
Hides navigation unnecessarily - use full menu

breadcrumbs.description: Secondary navigation showing user's location in site hierarchy.
breadcrumbs.usage: Use for multi-level sites with clear hierarchy (3+ levels deep).

dos_donts.rationale: Helps users understand where they are

dos_donts.do: Collapse to parent + current on mobile

pagination.description: Navigation for multi-page content sets like blog posts, search results, tables.
pagination.usage: Use for >25 items. For <25, consider showing all or infinite scroll.

mobile_variant.show: Prev / Page X of Y / Next

accessibility: Disabled buttons: aria-disabled='true' (stay in tab order)
Clear button labels for screen readers
Focus indicator visible on all buttons

dos_donts.do: Always show first and last page
Simplify on mobile (Prev / X of Y / Next)

dos_donts.dont: Use infinite scroll for critical content
dos_donts.rationale: Users can't bookmark or share specific pages

tooltip.description: Small contextual popup providing additional information on hover or focus.
tooltip.usage: Use for icon explanations, form field hints, feature descriptions.

positioning.note: Auto-adjust if tooltip would overflow viewport

accessibility: Trigger has aria-describedby pointing to tooltip ID
Tooltip appears on both hover AND focus
Don't put interactive elements inside tooltip
Ensure tooltip doesn't obscure important content

dos_donts.rationale: Tooltips should enhance, not be essential
Tooltips are for quick hints, not paragraphs

dos_donts.do: Make touch-friendly on mobile (tap to show)
dos_donts.rationale: Hover doesn't exist on touch devices
Tooltips are hidden by default - may be missed

dos_donts.dont: Put links or buttons in tooltips
dos_donts.rationale: Can't be reached with keyboard, breaks UX
Errors must be persistent and visible
Creates visual noise on every hover

popover.description: Larger contextual overlay for richer content, menus, or interactive elements.
popover.usage: Use for dropdown menus, color pickers, date pickers, rich tooltips.

triggers.click: Show on click, hide on outside click
triggers.hover: Show on hover (with delay), hide on mouse leave
triggers.focus: Show on focus, hide on blur

accessibility: Focus first interactive element when opened
Return focus to trigger on close

dos_donts.rationale: Unlike tooltips, popovers can contain buttons/links

dos_donts.do: Close on outside click or ESC
Show close button for non-obvious popovers

form.description: Structured layout for collecting user input with clear flow and validation.
form.usage: Use for contact forms, signup, checkout, surveys, settings.

field_layout.name: Two Column
field_layout.use: Related short fields (first name / last name)

validation.inline_validation: Show per-field errors immediately on blur

submit.width: full on mobile, auto on desktop

accessibility: Focus first error field on submit attempt

dos_donts.rationale: Every field reduces conversion - be ruthless
Easier to scan, better mobile UX, higher conversion

dos_donts.do: Show validation on blur, not while typing
Provide helpful error messages with solutions
Preserve user data if validation fails

dos_donts.rationale: Feels out of control, causes errors

dos_donts.dont: Use custom validation without HTML5 validation

table.description: Structured display of tabular data with rows, columns, and optional sorting/filtering.
table.usage: Use for datasets, pricing comparisons, feature matrices, admin panels.

dos_donts.do: Use monospace font for numeric data

dos_donts.rationale: Users need context to understand data
Long tables are overwhelming and slow
Tables break on small screens without adaptation
Use CSS Grid/Flexbox - tables are for data
Not all data benefits from sorting (actions, icons)

dos_donts.dont: Use tiny fonts (<14px) for table data
Truncate important data without expand option
dos_donts.rationale: Users need access to full information

tabs.description: Content organization pattern for switching between related views without navigation.
tabs.usage: Use for settings sections, product details, multi-step forms (non-linear).

mobile_behavior.stacked: Stack tabs vertically with full width

accessibility: Tab key moves to panel content
Home/End keys jump to first/last tab

dos_donts.rationale: Tabs work when content is peer-level
Too many tabs = consider different pattern

dos_donts.do: Show all tabs at once (don't hide in overflow)
dos_donts.rationale: Users need to see all options
Tabs often break on small screens
User should control view, not auto-carousel
Tabs are for content switching, not site navigation

divider.description: Visual separator for creating sections and hierarchy within content.
divider.usage: Use to separate unrelated content, create visual breaks, improve scannability.
accessibility: Use semantic <hr> element for thematic breaks

dos_donts.rationale: Major sections = more space, minor = less
Too many dividers create visual clutter

dos_donts.dont: Use dividers in place of proper headings
dos_donts.rationale: Headings provide semantic meaning and structure

dos_donts.dont: Make dividers too bold or colorful

skeleton.description: Loading placeholder that mimics content structure while data loads.
skeleton.usage: Use during initial page load or lazy loading to reduce perceived wait time.
accessibility: Remove skeleton and update aria-busy when loaded

dos_donts.do: Match skeleton to actual content structure

dos_donts.rationale: Looks more natural than uniform lines

dos_donts.do: Transition smoothly from skeleton to content

dos_donts.dont: Make skeleton too different from real content

progress_bar.description: Visual indicator of task completion or loading progress.
progress_bar.usage: Use for multi-step processes, file uploads, profile completion, course progress.

dos_donts.do: Use determinate when progress is calculable
Show percentage label for key processes

dos_donts.dont: Fake progress that doesn't reflect reality
dos_donts.rationale: Breaks trust when bar stalls at 99%

dos_donts.dont: Use progress bar for binary states
dos_donts.rationale: Use loading spinner or skeleton instead

avatar.description: Visual representation of a user or entity, typically circular with image or initials.
avatar.usage: Use for user profiles, comments, team members, testimonials.

states.name: Initials
states.content: First + Last initial (CM for Carolina Mendes)
states.background: primary-600 or dynamic based on name hash

accessibility: Use alt text for images: 'Photo of [Name]'
If clickable, provide clear label or context

dos_donts.do: Generate initials from name if no image
Use border on avatars over photos

dos_donts.rationale: Circles are standard for people, clear affordance
Use object-fit: cover to maintain aspect ratio

colors.note: Refer to Oitavo Café Color Palette for full color specifications

typography.font_family_secondary: DIN Pro Condensed (for labels, supporting text)

spacing.note: All spacing should be multiples of 8px

developer_handoff: All components use design tokens - never hardcode values
Color contrast validated to WCAG AA minimum (AAA preferred)
All interactive elements have focus states for keyboard navigation
Use semantic HTML elements for proper accessibility
Implement loading states for async operations
Provide meaningful error messages in friendly language
brand_voice_in_components: Button text: Action verbs, results-focused (Começar, Agendar, Baixar)
Error messages: Helpful and friendly, not technical ('Email precisa incluir @')
Success messages: Celebrate wins ('Pronto! Mensagem enviada.')
Helper text: Concise and practical, like talking to a friend

See also: Oitavo Café Branding Guidelines (oitavo-cafe-branding-guidelines.md)
